PROCHLORPERAZINE

ANTIPSYCHOTIC DRUGS

  • Pregnancy

  • Renal impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects

  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Schizophrenia and other psychoses, Mania,

By deep intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    12.5 mg twice daily for 7 days, dose to be adjusted at intervals of 4–7 days according to response; usual dose 75–100 mg daily.
  • For adults
    12.5–25 mg 2–3 times a day.

Short-term adjunctive management of severe anxiety,

By mouth

  • For adults
    15–20 mg daily in divided doses; maximum 40 mg per day.

Nausea and vomiting, acute attack,

By deep intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    Initially 20 mg, then 10 mg after 2 hours.
  • For adults
    12.5 mg as required, to be followed if necessary after 6 hours by an oral dose.

Nausea and vomiting, prevention,

By deep intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    5–10 mg 2–3 times a day.
  • For adults
    12.5 mg as required, to be followed if necessary after 6 hours by an oral dose.

Prevention and treatment of nausea,

By intramuscular injection

  • For children 1–11 years (body-weight 10 kg and above)
    250 micrograms/kg 2–3 times a day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    5–10 mg up to 3 times a day if required.
  • For children 2–4 years
    1.25–2.5 mg up to 3 times a day if required.
  • For children 5–11 years
    5–6.25 mg up to 3 times a day if required.
  • For children 12–17 years
    12.5 mg up to 3 times a day if required.

Labyrinthine disorders,

By mouth

  • For adults
    5 mg 3 times a day, increased if necessary to 30 mg daily in divided doses, dose to be increased gradually, then reduced to 5–10 mg daily, dose is reduced after several weeks.

Nausea and vomiting in previously diagnosed migraine,

By mouth using buccal tablet

  • For adults
    3–6 mg twice daily, tablets to be placed high between upper lip and gum and left to dissolve.
  • For children 12–17 years
    3–6 mg twice daily, tablets to be placed high between upper lip and gum and left to dissolve.

Dose equivalence and conversion

Doses are expressed as prochlorperazine maleate or mesilate; 1 mg prochlorperazine maleate ≡ 1 mg prochlorperazine mesilate.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Extrapyramidal effects and withdrawal syndrome have been reported occasionally in the neonate when antipsychotic drugs are taken during the third trimester of pregnancy.

Following maternal use of antipsychotic drugs in the third trimester, neonates should be monitored for symptoms including agitation, hypertonia, hypotonia, tremor, drowsiness, feeding problems, and respiratory distress.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Can precipitate coma; phenothiazines are hepatotoxic.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Start with small doses in severe renal impairment because of increased cerebral sensitivity.

Contra indications

  • Avoid oral route in child under 10 kg
  • children (in psychotic disorders)
  • CNS depression
  • comatose states
  • phaeochromocytoma

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Dystonic reactions, respiratory depression may occur in susceptible patients,

Acute dystonic reactions

Phenothiazines can all induce acute dystonic reactions such as facial and skeletal muscle spasms and oculogyric crises; children (especially girls, young women, and those under 10 kg) are particularly susceptible.

Directions for administration

With buccal use

Buccal tablets are placed high between upper lip and gum and left to dissolve.

Advice for patients and carers

With buccal use

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer prochlorperazine buccal tablets.

Cautions regarding administration

  • : Elderly in adults
  • hypotension (more likely after intramuscular injection)

Unlicensed use

With intramuscular use in children

Injection not licensed for use in children.

With buccal use in children

Buccal tablets not licensed for use in children.

Prepared medicinal forms of PROCHLORPERAZINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: suppository,
Tablet
Buccal tablet
Oral solution
Solution for injection
